reviewText: If one were to look for a cinematic approach to theology, this film may be one of the best examples of such a notion, in that it is a good biography of the early and middle portions of the pastoral life of John Wesley and to a lesser extent, his brother, Charles Wesley, the founders of the Methodist movement and denomination, out of their roots in the Church of England. What makes this theological is the importance of learning right living and faith from following the model of great exemplars such as Jesus and Paul. Both of these founders of Christianity preached emulation as the proper model for learning. In that role, the film may be more successful than some of the more flashy Hollywood products such as Ben-Hur and The Ten Commandments. The era of the Wesleys is not that far away, and their problems are very, very human. They are the kinds of problems we can run into every day.This film is not a major Hollywood product. It was made on the wrong coast, and not even in or near The Big Apple, the old, original home of the motion picture industry. It was made in North Carolina, by a Moravian, not even by a Methodist. But that is neither here nor there, as the movie achieves its objectives in an informative manner. While this will never be mistaken for an Indiana Jones flick, it succeeds in its own genre as well or better than most other pictures.Aside from the two familiar names in the cast, Kevin McCarthy and June Lockhart, and the actor in the title role, Burgess Jenkins, it seems as if the film was made by independants, for whom film making is not their "day job". I know, for example, that the co-writer and director, John Jackman, is a pastor at a North Carolina Moravian church who has produced one or two other films. In spite of that, there is less that is amateur or obviously artificial than you may find in a Hollywood exploitation film.Be aware that the film is not pure history. In a question and answer session after a screening of the film in Bethlehem, PA (Moravian Central) Jackman explained that several scenes were a composite of a series of meetings or events. But several of the more important events in the development of Wesley's beliefs are historically genuine, such as Wesley's being influenced by Moravians and by one of his more important epiphanies being prompted by his listening to a reading of an English translation of Martin Luther's commentary on the book of Romans. In response to a comment by another reviewer, Jackman also assured us that the costuming and locations for the film are quite accurate.For a film on a religious topic, by professional church folks, I confess the film is not as preachy as one may have expected. This is about real people and real situations, and how real people have their faith developed by life experiences and how great ideas can arise from seemingly incidental occurrences.This is a great film to show in a church. Unlike many such films, it can appeal to people of many different ages. To exhibit the film to a group such as a church, you need a license. Search the Internet for Wesley The Movie. The licenses are remarkably inexpensive if you add up admission per person charges in a commercial theatre.It ain't Avatar, but then, Avatar isn't good ecclesiastical history. Highly recommended.

reviewText: This is one great DVD and recommend it to any person who needs to see how a person begin with his small problems and became a world evangelist.  Wesley was a man who took the Word, the Church and the Lord Jesus to the world.  Unlike today where the political party is imposing its corruption in the Holy Church and on the world.  This DVD show how Wesley and his brother over came a politically corrupt government of his time.  The Methodist Church mission was to save the children,  help people know the worth of being one of God's own creation and Preach the Word.  Amen..  Much of Wesley's mission is being disregarded today, however, this DVD may be your first step in restoring the God kind of hope and salvation. It may give you and yours the insight to see what was going on at Wesley's time and what is going today.  With God's help The United Methodist Church will remember the Mission from Altersgate and return to Preaching the word and its one foundation, and its mission to aid all in need of Christ Holy Word.
summary: The Man who left out of the New church of today  is restored in this DVD

reviewText: Background:John Wesley (28 June 1703 - 2 March 1791) was an amazing evangelist. He was a brilliant theologian; however, his head knowledge and good works alone could not provide him with the peace and blessed assurance that a soul has when it is assured of its salvation.Eventually he has his encounter with the Holy Spirit and he is never the same, and his whole method of preaching changes which results in the formation of the Methodist Society.Film Production:This film is based on the personal journals of Mr John Wesley. It starts in 1709 at Epworth, England. There is a fire at his home, and he is rescued at the age of 5. This fire leaves a lasting impression on John Wesley - The film fast forwards and then shows John Wesley as a young man waking up from a nightmare of the fire. Other flashbacks of the fire are placed throughout the movie. Additionally, as his fame spreads abroad, he shows a strong reluctance to return to Epworth. However, he eventually overcomes this fear and returns.Fear of Death and Hell:John Wesley comes to the realization that his faith has something lacking, this was based on the calmness of the Moravians who were traveling along with him in a ship that was being heavily battered by a storm. This caused John Wesley to seek the missing part of his salvation even further.Overall Story:The life of John Wesley seems to be accurately portrayed in this film. The locations, incidents and events are well depicted. However, the later years of Wesley are not contained in this DVD.Conclusion:In my opinion, the message of John Wesley is that everyone needs to experience Jesus Christ personally. This is an excellent addition to any DVD collection, where there is an interest in the protestant reformation and the growth of the Church of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I semi-enjoyed this film.If one views this movie more as a filmed play with some graphics, rather than a movie it will play off better.  The movie was more of the story of Wesley's conversion to true faith in Christ, rather than a portrayal of his life and ministry (though such was lightly touched on following the probably less impactful shamed experience of John and Charles in Georgia, which seemed to be the greater part of focus in the film).  As many Christian films the majority of the acting and the special effects were unimpressive.  George Whitefield was a necesarry side-character, with whom I was unimpressed in the film, I was hoping they'd do a better job portraying him, as he was a powerful revivalist in English history and intregal in the assistance of the Methodist movement (specifically by aiding John and Charles in expanding their evangelistic view).  The most likeable character in the film is Charles Wesley, John's younger brother.
summary: Wesley: A Heart Transformed Can Change the World

reviewText: OVERALL I FOUND THIS VIDEO TO BE INSPIRING! It is a thoughtful and educational film, sensitively and skilfully portrayed by the lead characters. If you find it a bit slow-moving at first, stay tuned--it picks up and keeps moving until the end. A must for those interested in the Wesleys, the history of the Church of England, how the Methodist church was started, and for anyone who is struggling with the way of salvation in the Christian faith.

reviewText: I really like this movie.  You can't expect the greatest acting, however, it is in no way painful, especially if you are interested in the story being told.  From my study, the story has the general outline of events in his life, however, there is a lot of filler-content that is not accurate.  The way the story portrays his "fling" with the girl in Georgia does not seem to be accurate, and I think they tried very hard to portray certain attributes of his character that ended up being slightly exaggerated (such as his controlling nature).Overall, it's a good movie, but should be taken with a (big) grain of salt.
summary: A Wonderful Man- Somewhat Inaccurate Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off - a disclaimer - I saw this movie at a preview screening before the final cut was made.  Several aspects of the film's quality leaped out at me.  First, it is beautifully filmed.  Second, the acting by all of the primaries is wonderful.  Finally, as a bit of a Methodist historian myself (see my book "the Fruit of the Vine, a history of Methodism in the Southern Piedmont" on Amazon), I was very impressed with the historical accuracy of the film.  Most Methodists and Moravians known little of Wesley's years in Georgia and the fact that they were, with the exception of his organizing a small "Methodist" meeting there, a complete failure.The movie admirably portrays Wesley's awkwardness with women - a problem that plagued him throughout his life, as his later marriage was an utter disaster with a great deal of bitterness arising between him and his bride.  The movie also recreates the very real desire in Wesley's life to seek a right relationship with God and to be the servant he felt he was called to be.  The tensions this quest caused him, both personally and professionally, are briefly summarized in the final part of the version I saw and were interesting to see.Ultimately, I saw this movie and found myself more hopeful about not only my own Methodist faith (as the movie does not mince words on the call of the Gospel) and Christian film making.  I have since seen the film Billy, the Early Years and was equally pleased with the quality of its production.I am hopeful, because it has generally been my experience that most Christian films have sucked over the years.  I say this despite my being a Methodist pastor, but ultimately because I love movies and have been reluctant and always disappointed in the quality of Christian movies over the years.  I am now more hopeful and optimistic about the future of Christian film making and believe we are headed into a brighter future for the genre.
summary: Very Good Quality Christian Film - excellent for Methodists and Moravians alike

reviewText: Why do Chistian moviemakers have such a hard time putting together a quality movie??? I'll start with June Lockhart being given star billing, when she was only on screen for a few minutes -- and then she spoke in her natural American accent -- in England, portraying Susannah Wesley. Other American actors also spoke with definite American accents but they were supposed to be British and in England -- very distracting. The movie was rife with errors like that:  Wesley walking down the front stairs of a brick building in 18th century England...  but the stairs had tubular steel handrails. And then there's the issue of Wesley's ever-changing and sometimes unnatural hair color -- especially the gray stripe at the part in his hair that comes and goes from scene to scene -- very noticeable. Along with that, the movie is very s-l-o-w and the acting is very poor. I really wanted to learn more about the life and times of John Wesley... He has such an amazing story. But this movie didn't do it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: While I agree with the negative comments about the low cut dresses at the beginning of the movie, the movie was well done, with good acting and was really inspiring. Wesley's struggles with works verses faith and his moment of revelation concerning grace are really touching. His going through all of the British Isle's with good news of the gospel and after he had been kicked out of the Church of England, presenting it to the common man really blessed me. A holiness preacher, whose walk matched his talk, Wesley's legacy lives on today. He built schools, started orphanages, helped abolish slavery and more. For the low cut dresses, it receives a four instead of a five star review. We are to be in the world, but not of it. Having said that, I learned much about Wesley through this movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Wesley" does a fine job of bringing to life the critical years of his life.  People who know little but the name should carry away a vivid and sound impression; those who know more will appreciate the perspective that a good movie offers.The movie is a resounding success, if we take into account the scope of the film and the limitations of a modest budget.  It has clarity, good storytelling, satisfying visuals, and music to match.  Among the inevitable weaknesses is the problem of accent, which another review rightly calls "uneven."The copy we received is widescreen and fits our 16:9 (1.78) screen nicely.  It has subtitles, which are very important for old folks like us.  My wife called it "wonderful" and wanted to make sure we had our own copy.
